descript.abstract: The NHC official track forecast points in shapefile format is an experimental products that the National Hurricane Center is testing during the 2008 hurricane season. The points represent the official NHC forecast locations of the center of a tropical cyclone. Forecast center positions are given for projections valid 12, 24, 36, 48, 72, 96, and 120 h after the forecast's nominal initial time, provided that a closed surface wind circulation is expected to exist at the forecast projection time. It is important to remember that tropical cyclone track forecasts are subject to error, and that the effects of a tropical cyclone can span many hundreds of miles from the center.
descript.purpose: The points represent the official NHC forecast locations of the center of a tropical cyclone.

idinfo.useconst: None. Acknowledgement of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Weather Service, National Environmental Prediction Center or the National Hurricane Center would be appreciated in products derived from these data.

cntperp.cntorg: National Hurricane Center / Technical Support Branch

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.4.1420

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: name given to each tropical cyclone for which the National Hurricane Center is writing forecast advisories
category of the tropical cyclone according to the initial intensity
the time in which a forecast or warning is in effect, until it is updated or superseded by a new forecast issuance
the sequential numbering of forecast advisories for each tropical cyclone
the sequential numbering of tropical cyclones for a specific forecast basin according to when the first advisory is issued
the time interval for which the forecast of a tropical cyclone is provided in graphical format
the ocean where the tropical cyclone is located
distance north or south from the equator of the center of the tropical cyclone (decimal degrees)
distance east or west on the earth's surface from the prime meridian at Greenwich, England of the center of the tropcical cyclone (decimal degrees)
the date in which an advisory is issued
number of hours from the forecast valid time for which a forecast is made
the highest 1-minute average wind (at an elevation of 10 meters without an unobstructed exposure) associated with a tropical cyclone at a particular point in time (knots)
a rapid fluctuation of wind speed with variations of 10 knots or more between peaks and lulls (knots)
the estimated sea level pressure at the center of a tropical cyclone (the lowest pressure in the system in Millibars)
the best estimate of the direction that the center of a tropical cyclone is moving towards (degrees)
the best estimate of the speed in which the center of a tropical cyclone is moving (knots)

distinfo.distliab: No responsibility is assumed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in the use of these data.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata
